text:
Raskolnikov felt totally lost, not really knowing what he was doing or why. 

“I might bring you something else soon, Alyona Ivanovna—a nice silver cigarette box—when I get it back from a friend…” He trailed off, feeling awkward. 

“Sure, we can talk about it later,” she replied. 

“Bye—are you always home alone? Your sister isn’t here?” he asked, trying to sound chill as he headed for the door. 

“What’s it to you?” she shot back. 

“Just curious. No need to bite my head off… Good day, Alyona Ivanovna.” 

Once outside, Raskolnikov was a mess. The confusion only grew. He stopped a few times on the stairs, hit by sudden thoughts. When he hit the street, he yelled, “Oh, God, this is all so gross! Can I really… No, that’s ridiculous!” He shook his head. “How could I even think that? My heart is capable of such filth. It’s disgusting, just disgusting! And I’ve been…” But he couldn’t find the words to express how he felt. 

The intense disgust that had started to creep in while he was on his way to the old woman was now overwhelming. He didn’t know how to escape the misery. He stumbled along the sidewalk like he was drunk, bumping into people without a care.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences intense confusion and repulsion after visiting Alyona Ivanovna, reflecting on the disturbing thoughts that have plagued him.
